unnormalised: **Project Nilgiri Tahr: A Steep Climb Towards Preservation**
normalised: **Project Nilgiri Tahr: A Steep Climb Towards Preservation**

unnormalised: Coimbatore, Tamil Nadu – The Tamil Nadu Forest Department is intensifying efforts under Project Nilgiri Tahr, aiming to boost the population of this endangered mountain goat. Recent surveys conducted near Mukurthi National Park revealed a promising increase in sighting numbers, a testament to ongoing conservation strategies.
normalised: Coimbatore, Tamil Nadu – The Tamil Nadu Forest Department is intensifying efforts under Project Nilgiri Tahr, aiming to boost the population of this endangered mountain goat. Recent surveys conducted near Mukurthi National Park revealed a promising increase in sighting numbers, a testament to ongoing conservation strategies.

unnormalised: Experts from the Wildlife Institute of India (WII) are collaborating with local communities, including the Toda tribe, to implement habitat restoration projects and combat poaching. On 26/01/2024, a special workshop will be held at the Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (TNAU) to discuss innovative farming techniques that minimize human-wildlife conflict.
normalised: Experts from the Wildlife Institute of India (W I I) are collaborating with local communities, including the Toda tribe, to implement habitat restoration projects and combat poaching. On twenty-sixth January two thousand and twenty four, a special workshop will be held at the Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (T N A U) to discuss innovative farming techniques that minimize human-wildlife conflict.

unnormalised: This initiative, crucial to preserving India’s biodiversity, builds upon earlier efforts launched post-independence. We recall with pride that protecting our wildlife was considered even on 15/08/1947, during the first conservation debates. A special monitoring session is scheduled on 01/12/2023 at 09:00 hrs to assess the impact of current measures. The plan includes expanding protected areas by approximately 50 km and relocating invasive species by 2025. Understanding our responsibilities as stewards of the land is key to their success.
normalised: This initiative, crucial to preserving India’s biodiversity, builds upon earlier efforts launched post-independence. We recall with pride that protecting our wildlife was considered even on fifteenth August one thousand nine hundred and forty seven, during the first conservation debates. A special monitoring session is scheduled on first December two thousand and twenty three at zero nine hundred hours to assess the impact of current measures. The plan includes expanding protected areas by approximately fifty kilometer and relocating invasive species by two thousand and twenty five. Understanding our responsibilities as stewards of the land is key to their success.
